elements.name: consentform
elements.html:
Invitation to be a Part of a Research Study

Principal Investigator: Nathan Garay and Jamal Dari
Study Sponsor: University of Detroit Mercy

The purpose of this study is to investigate your understanding of technical terms that may be commonly found in privacy policies and whether you believe commonly misunderstood verbiage is appropriate or can be reworded for improved comprehension.

Your participation in the study is completely voluntary and you can stop your participation at any time without any penalty or loss. This survey should take you 20-25 minutes. You will be one of about 30 participants.

This project is unlikely to have more than minimal risk. The study team does not foresee or anticipate any risk greater than that encountered in your routine daily activities.

All of your responses will be kept anonymous beyond the demographic questions.

Some people who are part of this study may receive the benefit of better understanding future privacy policies they may encounter and changing their behavior regarding the acceptance of privacy policies.

The study is paid for by the University of Detroit Mercy and, therefore, there will be no cost to you aside from your time to answer the survey questions

You will not be identified in any reports on this study. Records will be kept confidential to the extent provided by federal, state, and local law. However, the Institutional Review Board, the sponsor of the study, or university and government officials responsible for monitoring this study may inspect these records.

Since this study will collect limited data from you, you should be aware that the data will not be used for commercial profit.

If significant new knowledge is obtained during the course of this research which may relate to your willingness to continue to be involved in this study, you will be informed of this knowledge.

Should you have questions regarding your rights as a research participant, or wish to obtain information, ask questions, or discuss with someone other than the researcher(s), please contact the Institutional Review Board at: Michelle A. Wheater, Ph.D., Professor of Integrated Biomedical Sciences, School of Dentistry, Room 430, 2700 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd, Detroit, MI 48208, (313) 494-6634, wheatemi@udmercy.edu.

The Principal Investigators (Nathan Garay and Jamal Dari) can be reached by email at garaynf@udmercy.edu and/or darija@udmercy.edu.

One copy of this document will be kept together with the research records of this study.

elements.name: consent
elements.title: I have read (or been informed of) the information given above. Nathan Garay and/or Jamal Dari have offered to answer any questions I have concerning the study. I agree and give my consent to be a part of this study.

questions.name: gender
questions.title: To which gender do you most identify?

questions.name: education
questions.title: What is the highest degree or level of education you have completed?
choices: High school graduate, diploma or GED certificate
Some postgraduate or professional education, no postgraduate degree
Postgraduate or professional degree, including master's, doctorate, medical, or law degree'

questions.name: income
questions.title: What was your total household income before taxes in the last year?

questions.name: ethnicity
questions.title: Are you of Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish origin?

questions.name: race
questions.title: Which of the following best describes you? Select all that apply
choices: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

questions.name: employment
questions.title: What is your current employment status?

questions.name: tech
questions.title: Have you ever received formal training in computer science, software engineering, IT, computer networks, or a related technical field?

elements.name: past
elements.title: Have you read a privacy policy in the last 3 months?

elements.name: often
elements.title: How often do you read privacy policies?

elements.name: behavior
elements.title: When you read privacy policies, which best describes the way that you read them? Select all that apply

elements.name: instructions
elements.html:
Now we will ask 15 questions to explore your intreptation of certain terms that are often used in privacy policies.

Please respond using only your prior knowledge; do NOT consult search engines such as Google.

questions.name: privacypolicy
questions.title: Which of these best describes the main purpose of a privacy policy?
choices: It explains how your data will be protected
It is a legal document that says how users' data will be collected and used
It explains how the company keeps confidential the information it collects on users
It says that the company will not share users' data with other sites or companies without permission

questions.name: keys
questions.title: Imagine that a company's data use policy states that, "We store your keys for up to 30 days." What is the most accurate definition of keys in this statement?
choices: Information that allows you to access your account without logging in every time

questions.name: donottrack
questions.title: If you send a Do Not Track request, are websites able to track you?

questions.name: browser
questions.title: Imagine that a company's data use policy states that, "We use browser web storage to store information about you." Where does this mean that information about you can be stored? Select all that apply.
choices: On machines or servers that are onsite to the company
On machines or servers in your local area

questions.name: local
questions.title: Imagine that a company's data use policy states that, "We use local storage to store information about you." Where does this mean that information about you can be stored? Select all that apply.
choices: On machines or servers that are onsite to the company
On machines or servers in your local area

questions.name: metadata
questions.title: Imagine that a company's data use policy states that, "We store metadata from your social media posts." What is the most accurate meaning of metadata in this statement?
choices: A better way of using data
A set of data or information
Data about data or files (e.g., time, size, location)

questions.name: metadata2
questions.title: Which of the following might be examples of metadata? Select all that apply.
choices: Who an email or message was sent to
Location where a photo was taken

questions.name: cryptographichash
questions.title: Imagine that a company says "We store a cryptographic hash of your password." What is the most accurate meaning of cryptographic hash in this context?
choices: We store an encrypted copy of your password
We store information that allows us to check your password, but we do store not your password in plain text
We store information that allows us to check your password, but no one will be able to learn your password from this information even if we get hacked
We store your password with extra security

questions.name: pixeltag
questions.title: Imagine that a company says "We use pixel tags and other similar technologies." What is the most accurate definition of pixel tag in this context?
choices: A way to identify an image
A small piece of color in an image
A way to monitor which sites users visit using a small image
A way to identify which people or objects are in an image

questions.name: webbeacon
questions.title: Imagine that a company says "We use web beacons and other similar technologies." What is the most accurate definition of web beacons in this context?
choices: A way to monitor which sites users visit using a small image
A tool that allows companies to access data on a user's device
A tool that transports data between servers
Identifies data that belongs to a specific user

questions.name: persistentcookies
questions.title: When are persistent cookies deleted? Check all that apply.
choices: You can manually delete them, and they are deleted then
They have an expiration date, and they are deleted then
When you sign out of the website
Until you close the tab or navigate away from the website

questions.name: incognito
questions.title: Does private browsing/incognito mode make you anonymous on the internet?

questions.name: incognito2
questions.title: When using private browsing/incognito mode, where is data from your browsing session stored? Please select all that apply.
choices: On machines or servers belonging to the websites browsed
On machines or servers belonging to third parties

questions.name: deidentified
questions.title: Can de-identified information ever be tied to you as an individual?

questions.name: anonymized
questions.title: Can anonymized information ever be tied to you as an individual?

elements.name: instructions2
elements.html:
Next, you will be shown the definitions of the terms discussed on the previous page and asked whether you think the term is appropriate or not.

If you would like to change any of your previous responses, do so now as you will not be able to when you begin the next section.

questions.name: instructions3
questions.html: Once you have finalized your answers from the previous set of questions, the correct definitions/context will be shown below.

questions.name: questionvis
questions.title: Have you selected your final answers from the previous set of questions?

questions.name: privacypolicyre
questions.title: Please indicate your thoughts on the following terms with their correct definitions/context given

columns.name: col1
choices: The term is appropriate for its meaning.
The term is appropriate but should be defined within the document if it is used.
The term is vague, misleading, or otherwise confusing and can be reworded.

columns.name: reword
columns.title: Type any term(s) that you think could be more appropriate or less confusing. This section is not required.

rows: A "privacy policy" is a legal document that says how users' data will be collected and used.
"Keys" describe information that is necessary to read/decode messages.
Websites are still able to track you if you send a "Do Not Track request"
A company storing information about you using "browser web storage" means the information is stored on your machine or device.
A company storing information about you using "local storage" also means the information is stored on your machine or device.
"Metadata" describes data about data or files (including size, time, location, message recipient(s), uploader(s))
A company using a "cryptographic hash" means they store information that allows them to check your password, but your password is not stored in plain text.
A "pixel tag" is a way to monitor which sites users visit using a small image.
A "web beacon" is also a way to monitor which sites users visit using a small image.
"Persistent cookies" can be manually deleted and have experation dates.
"Incognito mode"/"private browsing" does not make you anonymous on the internet. The data is stored on machines or servers belonging to either the websites browsed or third parties.
"De-identified information" can be tied to you as an individual.
"Anonymized information" can also be tied to you as an individual.
